content.subtitle: Great article and everything you say makes sense.

virtuals.subtitle: Great article and everything you say makes sense.

paragraphs.text: Hi William
paragraphs.name: beb7

paragraphs.text: Great article and everything you say makes sense.
paragraphs.name: 3b80

paragraphs.text: I read a fascinating article called These 8 Metrics Predicted 70% of Satisfaction at Work
paragraphs.name: 6f51

paragraphs.text: It suggests, also based on research, that quality of co-workers is the single biggest contributor to employee engagement…
paragraphs.name: 38ae

e0c457884d2e.title: 76% of high-performance employees say trade mastery, not money, most important in career decisions.

content.subtitle: Connecting with our people through trade mastery, instead of money, is key to productive and happy folks.

virtuals.subtitle: Connecting with our people through trade mastery, instead of money, is key to productive and happy folks.

paragraphs.text: 76% of high-performance employees say trade mastery, not money, most important in career decisions.
paragraphs.name: b6fe

paragraphs.text: Connecting with our people through trade mastery, instead of money, is key to productive and happy folks.

c5b19f85bf1b.title: While you’re correct that mastery is a driver for some people I think there is a minimum…

paragraphs.text: While you’re correct that mastery is a driver for some people I think there is a minimum requirement to at least be making within a reasonable range near the typical salary for any position. I’m working for a company who is keeping salaries below the 10th percentile of income and the morale and motivation is getting worse. Income/salaries are being…
paragraphs.name: 023c

content.subtitle: Your article reminds me of an old TED talk from Dan Pink (The puzzle of motivation). What you said resonates what everyone still aspires to…

virtuals.subtitle: Your article reminds me of an old TED talk from Dan Pink (The puzzle of motivation). What you said resonates what everyone still aspires to…

paragraphs.text: Hi William:
paragraphs.name: 85d7

paragraphs.text: Your article reminds me of an old TED talk from Dan Pink (The puzzle of motivation). What you said resonates what everyone still aspires to, including myself. My only fear is that this could be used as an pretext for offering below market salary, while expecting stellar performance.
paragraphs.name: 5fc3

9aba0d51141f.title: Yes thanks, I’ve seen that and I think you’re correct.

paragraphs.text: Yes thanks, I’ve seen that and I think you’re correct. I’m also seeing some interesting correlations with competency of direct manager—obviously right in line with your feedback.
paragraphs.name: e614

b17ec0e22fdb.title: Don’t underestimate the power of a killer paycheck.

content.subtitle: Making great money means the High-Performance Employee doesn’t have to think about money anymore; he can focus his intensity on other…

virtuals.subtitle: Making great money means the High-Performance Employee doesn’t have to think about money anymore; he can focus his intensity on other…

paragraphs.text: Don’t underestimate the power of a killer paycheck.
paragraphs.name: fa0a

paragraphs.text: Making great money means the High-Performance Employee doesn’t have to think about money anymore; he can focus his intensity on other priorities, including your critical projects.
paragraphs.name: 55a3

paragraphs.text: So don’t use “HPF’s are motivated by more intrinsic things” as an excuse to save a few bucks.
paragraphs.name: fa06

paragraphs.text: Although the outcome of your research is encouraging, I am wondering if the direct question “Are you motivated more by mastery of skill/craft, or motivated more by earning money?” yields socially acceptable answers — after all, it can be awkward to say…
paragraphs.name: eb32

paragraphs.text: Like any investment
paragraphs.name: 384d

paragraphs.text: William Belk
A decision to pursue trade mastery compounds like interest. In my experience taking this course pays much higher dividends the earlier it is prioritized.

paragraphs.text: The 23 year old, recent grad that chases trade mastery has 50+ years to compound on that…

paragraphs.text: Seems overthought, and a bit deceptive
paragraphs.name: eee1

paragraphs.text: When you talk about high-performance employees, you are talking about those who will be well paid regardless, so foregoing a little more more money in favor of much greater job satisfaction is not a mystery to me at all, for anyone
